text: In Greek mythology, Pandion (; Ancient Greek: Πανδίων means "all-divine") may refer to the following characters: * Pandion I, a legendary king of Athens, father of the sisters Procne and Philomela.Apollodorus, 3.14.6 * Pandion II, a legendary king of Athens, father of the brothers Aegeus, Pallas, Nisos and Lycus.Apollodorus, 3.15.5 * Pandion (hero), the eponymous hero of the Attic tribe Pandionis, usually assumed to be one of the legendary Athenian kings Pandion I or Pandion II.Pausanias, 1.5.3-5, 10.10.1. *Pandion, an Egyptian prince as son of Aegyptus and Hephaestine. He married Callidice, daughter of Danaus who killed him during their wedding night.Pseudo-Apollodorus. Bibliotheca, Book 2.1.5 * Pandion, son of Phineus and Cleopatra, brother of Plexippus. He and his brother were blinded by Phineus at the instigation of their stepmother Idaea.Pseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 3. 15. 3 *Pandion, from Phaestus in Crete, was father of Lamprus.Antoninus Liberalis. Metamorphoses, 17 * Pandion, an Achaean warrior who carried the bow of Teucer during the Trojan War.Homer. Iliad, 12.372 *Pandion, father of a certain Helen who consorted with Zeus and bore him a son, Musaeus.Pseudo-Clement, Recognitions 10.21-23 == References == Category:Characters in Greek mythology
title: Pandion (mythology)
